contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox political party | |country = Colombia |name_english = Colombian Liberal Party |name_native = Partido Liberal Colombiano |colorcode = red |party_logo = [[File:Logo del Partido Liberal Colombiano.jpg|200px]] |foundation = {{start date|1848}} |ideology = [[Social democracy]]<br>[[Social liberalism]]<br>[[Liberalism in Colombia|Liberalism]] |position = [[Centre-left]] |international = [[Socialist International]] |colours = [[Red]] |headquarters = [[Bogotá]], [[Colombia]] |members = |international = [[Socialist International]] |seats2_title = Seats in the [[Chamber of Representatives of Colombia|Chamber of Representatives]] |seats2 = {{Infobox political party/seats|38|166|hex=#FF0000}} |seats1_title = Seats in the [[Senate of Colombia|Senate]] |seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|17|102|hex=#FF0000}} |website = [http://www.partidoliberal.org.co/ http://www.partidoliberal.org.co/] }} {{La Violencia}} The '''Colombian Liberal Party''' ({{lang-es|Partido Liberal Colombiano}}; PLC) is a [[center-left]] party in [[Colombia]] that adheres to [[social democracy]] and [[social liberalism]]. The party was founded in 1848 and, together with the [[Colombian Conservative Party]], subsequently became one of the two main political forces in the country for over a century. After the period known as [[La Violencia]] the Liberals and the Conservative Party reached an agreement to share power from 1958 to 1974 in the so-called [[National Front (Colombia)|National Front]] agreement that followed the fall of General [[Gustavo Rojas Pinilla]]. Nowadays there are many critics of the 16-year agreement but it has to be admitted that it greatly reduced the intensity of the violent political warfare that preceded it. In the year 2002, the Liberal Party was the largest single party in the Colombian Congress, with 54 out of 166 deputies, and 28 of 102 senators. In the [[Colombian legislative election, 2006|election of 2006]], the party won 38 out of 166 Deputies and 18 out of 102 senators. With the election of independent [[List of Presidents of Colombia|President of Colombia]], [[Álvaro Uribe|Álvaro Uribe Vélez]] as president the Liberal party reached its greatest crisis ever. Alvaro Uribe is indeed a former member of the party, having crafted all of his political career prior to his election (where he ran as an independent Liberal) inside it, and has the strong backing of a substantial majority of the former Liberal elected congressmen (classified as "Uribist" Liberals by the media). The party's crisis has many reasons different from President Uribe's election and subsequent re-election, but the evident divide among the leadership has greatly diminished the support to the Colombian party, which was previously the most popular in the country. Most of the current "Officialist" (as named by the Colombian press) leadership of the Liberal Party is openly opposed to Uribe's government and his policies. In an effort to maintain some unity the party's selected in June 2005 former president [[César Gaviria Trujillo]] as their current chief. During the presidential elections of 28 May 2006, the official liberal candidate [[Horacio Serpa Uribe]] won 11.84% of the popular vote, placing him third. During the parliamentary elections of 14 March 2010, the Liberal Party obtained 18 senators and 35 representatives.
